newsitem.title: INDIA: India to decide soon on fresh sugar exports.
newsitem.headline: India to decide soon on fresh sugar exports.

text.p: India is likely to take a decision soon on allowing fresh 500,000 tonnes of sugar for exports in the 1996/97 (Oct-Sept) season, Commerce Minister B. B. Ramaiah said on Friday.
India in June authorised the food ministry to allow, in phases, export of one million tonnes of sugar in 1996/97.
"Possibly another half-a-million tonnes we can easily allow. We are still thinking on it," Ramaiah said at the annual general meeting of the Indian Sugar Mills Association (ISMA).
Ramaiah said the government was waiting for the assessment of the Agriculture Ministry on climatic factors and the status of this season's cane crop.
"We are still considering all this," the minister said.
But industry officials said that they were incurring losses in exports due to a dip in international prices and the Indian government's control over domestic sugar prices.
The Indian sugar industry expects 1995/96 sugar output at 16.45 million tonnes against 14.6 in the previous season. ISMA forecasts output in 1996/97 at 16 million tonnes.
India annually consumes about 13 million tonnes of sugar.
ISMA president Vivek Saraogi said India had surplus sugar stocks of 5.5 million tonnes at the beginning of the the new season on October 1.
"Against this disposable surplus, the government has created a buffer stock of a mere 500,000 tonnes and sanctioned an export of one million tonnes," Saraogi said.
He said this had posed serious problems leading to as severe liquidity cruch, a rising interest rate burden and low open market sugar prices.
Ramaiah said the government was considering creating an additional buffer stock over and above the 500,000 tonnes.
Saraogi demanded deregulation of sugar prices to minimise fluctuations in output and reduce losses on exports.
Production and pricing of sugar in India are controlled by the government.

The mills supply 40 percent of their output as levy at a subsidised rate for distribution among the poor. The government controls the release of the remainder on to the free market through the use of sales quotas.
Ramaiah said deregulation of sugar prices needed careful examination.
He said India should explore the possibility of more exports to nearby countries like Sri Lanka, Indonesia, Pakistan and the Gulf countries.
